'''Joseph Louis François Bertrand''' (11 March 1822 – 5 April 1900, born and died in Paris) was a [[France|French]] [[mathematician]] who worked in the fields of [[number theory]], [[differential geometry]], [[probability theory]], [[economics]] and [[thermodynamics]].<ref>[https://archive.org/details/logesacadmiq00bertuoft Éloge historique de Joseph Bertrand par Gaston Darboux (1902)]</ref>

==Biography==

Bertrand was a professor at the [[École Polytechnique]] and [[Collège de France]]. He was a member of the Paris Academy of Sciences and was its permanent secretary for twenty-six years. He was the son of physician [[Alexandre Jacques François Bertrand]] and the brother of archaeologist [[Alexandre Bertrand]]. His father died when Joseph was only nine years old, but that did not stand in his way of learning and understanding algebraic and elementary geometric concepts, and he also could speak Latin fluently, all when he was of the same age of nine.
At eleven years old he attended the course of the [[École Polytechnique]] as an auditor (open courses). From age eleven to seventeen, he obtained two bachelor's degrees, a license and a PhD with a thesis on the mathematical theory of electricity and is admitted first to the 1839 entrance examination of the [[École Polytechnique]].

He conjectured, in 1845, that there is at least one prime between ''n'' and 2''n'' − 2 for every ''n'' > 3. [[Pafnuty Chebyshev|Chebyshev]] proved this conjecture, now called [[Bertrand's postulate]], in 1850. He was also famous for a paradox in the field of [[probability]], now known as [[Bertrand paradox (probability)|Bertrand's Paradox]]. There is another paradox in [[game theory]] that is named after him, called the [[Bertrand paradox (economics)|Bertrand Paradox]].

Bertrand translated into French [[Carl Friedrich Gauss]]'s work on the [[theory of errors]] and the [[method of least squares]].

In the field of [[economics]] he reviewed the work on [[oligopoly]] theory, specifically the [[Cournot competition|Cournot Competition Model]] (1838) of French mathematician [[Antoine Augustin Cournot]]. His [[Bertrand competition|Bertrand Competition Model]] (1883) argued that Cournot had reached a very misleading conclusion, and he reworked it using prices rather than quantities as the strategic variables, thus showing that the [[Economic equilibrium|equilibrium]] price was simply the competitive price.

His book [http://gallica.bnf.fr/notice?N=FRBNF30098024 Thermodynamique] points out in Chapter XII, that thermodynamic entropy and temperature are only defined for reversible processes. He was one of the first people to point this out.

In 1858 he was elected a foreign member of the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]].

==Works by Bertrand==
* ''[http://gallica.bnf.fr/notice?N=FRBNF30098036 Traité de calcul différentiel et de calcul intégral]'' (Paris : Gauthier-Villars, 1864-1870) (2 volumes treatise on calculus)
* ''[http://gallica.bnf.fr/notice?N=FRBNF30098020 Rapport sur les progrès les plus récents de l'analyse mathématique]'' (Paris: Imprimerie Impériale, 1867) (report on recent progress in mathematical analysis)
* ''[http://gallica.bnf.fr/notice?N=FRBNF30098025 Traité d'arithmétique]'' (L. Hachette, 1849) (arithmetics)
* ''[http://gallica.bnf.fr/notice?N=FRBNF30098024 Thermodynamique]'' (Paris : Gauthier-Villars, 1887)
* ''[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k996041 Méthode des moindres carrés]'' (Mallet-Bachelier, 1855) (translation of [[Carl Friedrich Gauss|Gauss]]'s work on [[least squares]])
* ''[http://gallica.bnf.fr/notice?N=FRBNF30098013 Leçons sur la théorie mathématique de l'électricité / professées au Collège de France]'' (Paris : Gauthier-Villars et fils, 1890)
* ''[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k99602b Calcul des probabilités ]'' (Paris : Gauthier-Villars et fils, 1889)<ref>{{cite journal|author=Davis, Ellery W.|title=Review: ''Calcul des Probabilités'', par J. * ''[http://gallica.bnf.fr/notice?N=FRBNF30097972 Arago et sa vie scientifique]'' (Paris : J. Hetzel, 1865) (biography of Arago)
* ''[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k681143 Blaise Pascal]'' (Paris : C. Lévy, 1891) (biography)
* ''[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k777319 Les fondateurs de l'astronomie moderne: Copernic, Tycho Brahé, Képler, Galilée, Newton]'' (Paris: J. Hetzel, 1865) (biographies)
